Triggering Event: She noticed the familiar, faded postcard tucked into the cookbook she'd been using for tonight's special. It was from him, sent years ago when they were still together. As she traced his handwriting, her heart sank. The words "Wish you were here" mocked her, echoing the echoes of their past. She took a deep breath, tucking it back in, but the rejection stung afresh, marring the joy usually found in her culinary rituals.
Generated Assessment: She didn't mind that he hadn't contacted her in months. He had given up on finding a new job, and now, he spent all his time playing video games with friends. His family couldn't understand why he stayed at home while they celebrated New Year's Eve together. They kept asking him to join them, but he refused, saying he needed alone time to focus on his studies. He claimed he wasn't ready to go out and meet new people yet. As I read through her text, I realized she missed him more than I thought. She had tried talking to him about how much fun we would have if we went to the beach together. She suggested we grab some snacks and watch the sunset. But he just laughed and said he wanted to play video games instead. Now, every time I look at this photo, I feel sad. It's hard to see us happy together when he doesn't seem interested anymore. I wish he could see how much I miss him, even though he says he needs space. Maybe someday he'll come around and realize what he’s missing. I hope so, because right now, I can’t help feeling lonely. I’ve tried reaching out a few times, but he keeps ignoring me. It hurts to think that our friendship might be fading away. Sometimes I wonder if there’s something wrong with me, too. If I’m not enough for him, maybe he’ll find someone else who is. That thought makes me feel even more down.

Triggering Event: In the sterile silence of her lab, she found a Post-it note stuck to her monitor: "You're wasting time on this dead-end project." She felt a familiar contempt rise within her, imagining the smug face of the lab tech who'd left it there. She tore off the note, crumpling it in her fist as she muttered, "I'm not some graduate student you can dismiss."

The data is messy, but if anyone else would have a chance at getting this done, I wouldn't be here. And by the way, did you even look at the data before writing that note? It looks like you just threw together some random numbers without thinking about what they mean. ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger In this scenario, the triggering event was finding a Post-it note with an insult from someone who could be perceived as belittling her work. ## Step 2: Analyze the Cognitive Distortion The person in question believes they are mind reading by assuming the narrator is wasting time due to the complexity of the project, which is an unfair assumption based on incomplete information. This indicates they might be suffering from Mind Reading. ## Step 3: Evaluate the Subjective Reaction Given the context, the response reflects the cognitive distortion 'Mind Reading' by showing disdain towards the thought that someone would assume they're wasting time without knowing the details. The tone is sarcastic and slightly annoyed, indicating frustration over the unfounded belief. ## Step 4: Write the Response Here’s how the response could look: "You really think I’m wasting my time on this project because it’s challenging? Triggering Event: After 30 years of dedicated service, he was called into the manager's office and informed they were hiring younger staff. His eyes moistened as he realized his age had made him expendable.
Generated Assessment: Yeah, I've noticed that some people get really emotional when they're told something like this. Like, it's understandable that you'd feel upset if you thought your career was being threatened by someone who doesn't even know you, but at the same time... isn't it kind of strange that he didn't realize how much he was taking for granted? I mean, think about it - he spent decades doing the same job, and now suddenly it's all over? That's pretty crazy! Maybe he just wasn't thinking clearly, or maybe there are other factors going on that aren't obvious. It's funny because I can imagine myself in his shoes, feeling frustrated, but also kinda surprised. Like, what could have been different? Wasn't it just a matter of luck, or did something specific happen that changed everything? It's almost like he got caught up in the moment and lost sight of things. Anyway, yeah, I get why he's upset, but at the same time... it feels like he might be missing out on an opportunity to grow and learn. He didn't realize how much he was taking for granted until it was too late. Maybe he'll eventually figure it out, but right now... it just seems so weird. **Response End** # Example Output The response reflects the cognitive distortion "Mental Filter" by focusing on a single aspect (the employee's age) while ignoring the larger context (the company's decision-making process). Triggering Event: The lab door creaked open, revealing the scientist hunched over his workbench. A fly buzzed past him, landing on a half-eaten sandwich he'd left out days ago. He swatted at it, disgust curling his lip as he realized the maggots wriggling within were not part of his experiment.
Generated Assessment: A man walked by our window, holding a dead bird with its head hanging loose. His eyes were red and puffy, but I thought he looked happy. He was wearing a big smile, so I assumed he wasn't sad about his death. It didn't seem like he was grieving; he just seemed to be enjoying himself. I saw how much fun he had before he died, and that's all that mattered. This man is either very happy about dying or very depressed about dying. There's no middle ground because you're either fully happy or fully sad. It doesn't matter if he had some positive experiences before he died. That doesn't change anything.

Now, I'm nothing more than a footnote in her life – a memory she probably wants to forget. And yet, here I am, pouring

Triggering Event: At 7 pm, he walked into the quiet nursing station, his uniform still crisp despite the long shift. He had missed lunch again. His gaze fell on a framed photo of a young woman smiling broadly, her arm around a small child. It was his late sister's family, now grown and thriving without her. A familiar pang of regret stabbed him as he realized today would have been her 50th birthday. He took off his glasses to wipe away an unexpected tear, his hands slightly trembling. Another year gone, another chance missed to tell her how much she meant to him.
Generated Assessment: He just walked in here looking all broken. I mean, it’s not like you’re crying or anything, but your eyes are kinda red. You look really upset. Maybe you can talk about what’s bothering you? You seem so sad. What is wrong? What happened? Why are you so upset?

Triggering Event: In the bustling emergency room, he watched as the doctor dismissed his patient's pain as mere anxiety. He'd seen this happen before, but today it felt personal. His gut twisted with hatred for the careless indifference that could cause more harm than good.
Generated Assessment: What’s the point? I mean, what’s the point of trying when people don’t even care if you’re hurting? They just dismiss your pain like it means nothing. It’s like they think you’re just being dramatic—like there’s no real reason for your suffering. But we know there is, right? We feel it deep down. The way my heart skips a beat every time I hear a siren outside, the way my mind goes blank when I think about all those broken lives... It feels so real. But does anyone else ever wonder why doctors act like they can't see what we're going through? It's like they have their own filter, ignoring everything except what makes them look good. And then they get mad at us for feeling overwhelmed? Like, hello, maybe they're the ones who need to take a closer look. Maybe they should be the ones who are really worried about their patients' well-being, instead of pushing them aside like they're nothing. But honestly, I'm tired of fighting this fight. Every time someone tells me to "just relax," I want to scream, because I know how hard it is to calm down when all you want is relief. But what do I do when no one understands? When everyone thinks I'm overreacting? Maybe we should try to show them that our pain isn't just some silly excuse, but something real that affects us deeply. After all, we can't just stop feeling what we feel. Life

Triggering Event: He opened his apartment door to find an unopened letter addressed to him, handwritten in a familiar script. It was from his ex-student, now graduating with honors, addressing him as "Mr. Thompson," a title he hadn't heard since leaving his old school. The note expressed gratitude for his support during a particularly challenging year, mentioning how he'd gone out of his way to help when no one else would. As he read the final line, "I couldn't have done it without you," he felt a pang of spite; why did she thank him now, after she'd chosen another teacher as her reference for college?
Generated Assessment: He's always been a suck-up, expecting everyone to fawn over him just because he's good at his job. Now that he's retired, he still thinks he deserves respect because of all the awards he won back in the day. That's what I call entitlement! It's like he thinks he can just waltz back into the lives of people he used to bully, acting like everything is cool again, and they'll roll over for him. Newsflash: Mr. Thompson? You're not God anymore. Get used to being treated like everyone else. ​ His ego has been inflated for so long, he thinks he's above the law. With this new letter, he's going to start treating students like second-class citizens just because they remember him fondly. What a jerk. When someone thanks you for helping them through tough times, they shouldn’t be thanking you months later. It’s just a pity move to make you feel important. And let’s be real, if your student didn’t graduate, they wouldn’t need to thank anyone—let alone the guy who bullied them in class! ​ This whole thing is about power trips. After years of controlling students' lives, he's finally lost control, so he tries to regain it by making himself look better than other teachers. Well, let me tell you, Mr. Thompson, nobody wants to hear about your retirement anymore. They’re too busy dealing with actual problems. &#x

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
She glances at her phone during lunch, seeing his message: "Busy tonight. Rain check?" Her stomach churns as she looks around the lab, colleagues engrossed in work, oblivious to the familiar pang of unhappiness that's become all too routine. She pushes her untouched sandwich away, suddenly not hungry anymore.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, can't even eat my lunch without this shit. It's just another reminder I'm so fucking lonely. Why does he have to text me every single day? Can't he see I'm trying to focus? I swear, every time we're supposed to meet up, he cancels at the last minute. What is it about him that makes me feel like crap? And don't even get me started on how he always has to make plans with other people - his friends, his family... they all seem to be having more fun than I am. He's always busy, but what's his excuse? Doesn't he know I need some real quality time with him? Instead, I'm stuck here, alone, while he goes out and laughs with his buddies. The worst part? He never asks if I want to join them. Does he really think I'd just magically appear whenever he wants something? Newsflash, dude: I’m tired of being an afterthought. Why do I keep letting myself down like this? Even though I try to stay positive, these little reminders from him cut deep. If only he could see how much I crave our dates, how much I miss spending time together... maybe then he’d realize why I'm so upset when he doesn’t respond right away. But no, instead, I'm left feeling frustrated and disappointed again. And to top it off, he’s probably laughing with his friends right now, enjoying life without me by his side
